Importance of Silat ar-Rahm (Maintaining Family Ties)

Silat ar-Rahm (maintaining family ties) is one of the most emphasized and rewarded acts of worship in Islam. It is so fundamental that Allah has joined it with His own name and made it obligatory upon every Muslim. The Arabic term "ar-Rahm" literally means "the womb," signifying the blood ties that connect family members, and "Silat" means connection or joining.

The Supreme Command of Allah:

Allah commands in the Quran: "And fear Allah through whom you ask one another, and the wombs. Indeed Allah is ever, over you, an Observer." (Quran 4:1)

This verse establishes that maintaining family ties is not merely a social custom but a religious obligation. Allah watches how we treat our relatives and will hold us accountable.

"Worship Allah and associate nothing with Him, and to parents do good, and to relatives, orphans, the needy, the near neighbor, the neighbor farther away..." (Quran 4:36)

Allah places kindness to relatives immediately after the command to worship Him alone, showing its supreme importance.

What Exactly is Silat ar-Rahm?

Silat ar-Rahm encompasses:

1. Emotional Connection:
• Showing genuine love and affection to relatives
• Caring about their wellbeing
• Feeling joy at their happiness and sadness at their pain
• Maintaining warm relationships

2. Physical Presence:
• Regular visits and face-to-face interaction
• Attending family gatherings and celebrations
• Being present during times of need
• Not abandoning them despite distance

3. Financial Support:
• Helping poor relatives with money and resources
• Sharing wealth during difficult times
• Giving priority to needy relatives over strangers
• The Prophet ﷺ said: "Charity to the poor is charity, and charity to a relative is two things: charity and upholding the ties of kinship." (Tirmidhi)

4. Communication:
• Calling, messaging, and staying in touch
• Checking on their health and circumstances
• Sharing news and important events
• Using modern technology to bridge distances

5. Emotional and Practical Support:
• Helping during illness or hardship
• Providing advice and guidance
• Mediating in conflicts
• Standing up for them when needed

6. Respect and Honor:
• Speaking well of them
• Defending their reputation
• Showing respect, especially to elders
• Avoiding gossip or backbiting about family

Who Are Considered Your Relatives (Rahim)?

Islam defines relatives broadly:

1. Close Relatives (Mahram):
• Parents, grandparents, great-grandparents
• Children, grandchildren, great-grandchildren
• Siblings (full, half, and foster)
• Uncles and aunts (both paternal and maternal)
• Nephews and nieces

2. Extended Relatives:
• Cousins (all degrees)
• Great uncles and great aunts
• Second cousins and beyond
• All those connected by blood
• In-laws also deserve kindness and respect

The Prophet ﷺ was asked: "Who are most entitled to my good companionship?" He said: "Your mother." The man asked: "Then who?" He said: "Your mother." The man asked: "Then who?" He said: "Your mother." The man asked: "Then who?" He said: "Your father, then your nearest relatives according to the order of closeness." (Bukhari & Muslim)

Immense Rewards of Maintaining Family Ties:

1. Increased Lifespan:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "Whoever would like his provision to be increased and his lifespan to be extended should maintain family ties." (Bukhari & Muslim)

This doesn't necessarily mean living more years, but also means:
• Barakah (blessing) in time
• Productive and meaningful life
• Remembrance after death
• Legacy through righteous children

2. Increased Provision (Rizq):
• Allah blesses the wealth of those who maintain ties
• Business prospers
• Income increases
• Resources are sufficient
• Money is spent in beneficial ways

3. Entry to Paradise:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "The one who perfectly maintains the ties of kinship is not the one who does it because he gets reciprocated by his relatives, but the one who truly maintains the bonds is the one who, when his relatives cut him off, he keeps on maintaining the ties of kinship with them." (Bukhari)

Maintaining ties even when relatives are difficult earns the highest reward and entry to Jannah.

4. Protection from Calamities:
• Protects from sudden death
• Shields from misfortunes
• Brings Allah's mercy upon the person
• Easier death and good end

5. Quick Acceptance of Prayers:
• Duas are answered faster
• Supplications are not rejected
• Allah's mercy descends
• The Prophet ﷺ said: "Ar-Rahm (the womb/family ties) is suspended from the Throne and says: 'Whoever keeps me, Allah will keep him, and whoever severs me, Allah will sever him.'" (Bukhari & Muslim)

6. Love and Mercy from Allah:
"The merciful will be shown mercy by the Most Merciful. Be merciful to those on earth and the One above the heavens will have mercy upon you." (Tirmidhi)

7. Removal of Sins:
Maintaining ties despite difficulties expiates sins and raises one's status in Paradise.

Severe Punishment for Breaking Family Ties:

Breaking family ties (Qat ar-Rahm) is among the major sins in Islam:

1. Barrier to Paradise:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "The one who severs the ties of kinship will not enter Paradise." (Bukhari & Muslim)

This means entry will be delayed until purification or may be denied entirely without sincere repentance.

2. Quick Punishment in This World:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "There is no sin more deserving of having the punishment hastened in this world, in addition to what is stored up for the perpetrator in the Hereafter, than oppression and severing the ties of kinship." (Abu Dawud & Tirmidhi)

This includes:
• Loss of barakah in wealth and time
• Family problems and conflicts
• Difficulty in life affairs
• Children who disobey
• Hardship and stress

3. Prayers Not Accepted:
When family ties are severed, prayers and duas are not answered. Allah's mercy is withheld from those who show no mercy to relatives.

4. Allah Severs His Connection:
Just as one severs ties with family, Allah severs His mercy and blessings from that person.

5. Curse and Deafness:
"Would you then, if you were given authority, cause corruption on earth and sever your ties of kinship? Those are the ones that Allah has cursed, so He deafened them and blinded their vision." (Quran 47:22-23)

10 Practical Ways to Maintain Family Ties:

1. Regular Visits:
• Visit relatives frequently, not just on special occasions
• Don't wait for them to visit first
• Make time despite busy schedules
• Visit especially during illness or hardship
• The Prophet ﷺ would visit his relatives regularly

2. Phone Calls and Messages:
• Call to check on their wellbeing
• Message on special occasions
• Use video calls if living far
• Share good news and important updates
• Modern technology makes it easy - no excuses!

3. Gifts and Presents:
• The Prophet ﷺ said: "Give gifts and you will love one another." (Bukhari)
• Remember birthdays, Eid, weddings
• Give without expecting anything in return
• Gifts strengthen bonds and remove resentment

4. Financial Help:
• Support poor relatives before helping strangers
• Give charity to family members in need
• Help with education, medical expenses, etc.
• Do it with dignity and respect

5. Attend Family Gatherings:
• Weddings, funerals, celebrations
• Be present during important events
• Organize family reunions
• Create opportunities for family bonding

6. Make Dua for Them:
• Pray for their health, wealth, and guidance
• Make dua by name for each relative
• Supplication for family is always answered
• The Prophet ﷺ would make dua for his family

7. Forgive and Overlook:
• Don't hold grudges
• Forgive mistakes and shortcomings
• Overlook minor issues
• Be the bigger person
• "And let them pardon and overlook. Would you not like that Allah should forgive you?" (Quran 24:22)

8. Help in Times of Need:
• Be there during illness, death, financial crisis
• Provide practical support
• Emotional comfort and encouragement
• Stand up for them when wronged

9. Mediate in Conflicts:
• Bring feuding relatives together
• Act as peacemaker
• Don't fuel disputes
• Seek reconciliation
• Making peace between relatives is a great act of worship

10. Speak Well of Them:
• Mention their good qualities
• Defend their honor in their absence
• Don't gossip or backbite
• Protect family reputation

Special Cases: What If Relatives Are Difficult?

1. If They Wrong You:
• Still maintain ties from your side
• The Prophet ﷺ said: "The one who perfectly maintains the ties of kinship is not the one who does it because he gets reciprocated by his relatives, but the one who truly maintains the bonds is the one who, when his relatives cut him off, he keeps on maintaining the ties of kinship with them." (Bukhari)
• Don't cut ties in response to their cutting
• Be the better person
• Your reward is with Allah

2. If They Are Rude or Disrespectful:
• Respond with kindness and patience
• "Repel [evil] by that [deed] which is better; and thereupon the one whom between you and him is enmity [will become] as though he was a devoted friend." (Quran 41:34)
• Don't match their bad behavior
• Maintain your good character

3. If They Are Sinful:
• Maintain ties while disapproving of sin
• Advise them with wisdom and kindness
• Don't support their wrongdoing
• Make dua for their guidance
• Never sever ties due to their sins

4. If Distance Separates You:
• Use phone, video calls, messages
• Visit when possible
• Send gifts and financial support
• Distance is not an excuse to cut ties
• Technology has made it easier than ever

The Prophetic Example:

The Prophet Muhammad ﷺ was the perfect example of maintaining family ties:

• He maintained close ties with his uncle Abu Talib despite his disbelief
• He honored his aunt Safiyyah and other relatives
• He visited sick relatives and attended their funerals
• He gave priority to family in charity
• He reconciled feuding relatives
• He taught his companions to maintain ties even with difficult relatives
• He made maintaining family ties a condition for entering Paradise

Action Plan for Strengthening Family Ties:

1. Make a list of all your relatives
2. Identify those you haven't contacted recently
3. Start with closest relatives (parents, siblings, grandparents)
4. Reach out this week - call, visit, or message
5. Set regular reminders to stay in touch
6. Plan family gatherings or reunions
7. Help relatives in need
8. Forgive past grievances
9. Make daily dua for all your family
10. Make sincere intention to please Allah through maintaining ties

Remember: Every act of kindness toward relatives is rewarded abundantly. Every phone call, every visit, every kind word is recorded with Allah and will benefit you in this life and the Hereafter. Silat ar-Rahm is not just about fulfilling obligations - it's about building a strong, loving family that supports each other and pleases Allah.

May Allah help us all maintain strong bonds with our families and grant us the reward of Jannah through upholding Silat ar-Rahm. Ameen.

صلہ رحمی کی اہمیت

صلہ رحمی اسلام میں سب سے زیادہ زور دیے گئے اعمال میں سے ایک ہے۔

صلہ رحمی کیا ہے:
• لفظی معنی "رحم کو جوڑنا" - خونی رشتوں کو برقرار رکھنا
• رشتہ داروں سے مہربانی، ملاقات، مدد اور محبت شامل ہے
• تمام خاندانی اراکین - قریبی اور دور کے
• صرف ان تک محدود نہیں جو آپ کے ساتھ اچھے ہیں

بڑے ثواب:
• "اور اللہ سے ڈرو جس کے نام پر تم ایک دوسرے سے مانگتے ہو، اور رحموں سے۔ بیشک اللہ تم پر نگران ہے۔" (قرآن 4:1)
• عمر اور رزق میں اضافہ
• نبی کریم ﷺ نے فرمایا: "جو چاہے کہ اس کا رزق بڑھے اور عمر دراز ہو، وہ صلہ رحمی کرے۔" (بخاری و مسلم)
• مال اور اولاد میں برکت
• اچانک موت سے حفاظت

جنت میں داخلہ:
• صلہ رحمی جنت کا راستہ ہے
• نبی کریم ﷺ نے فرمایا: "تم جنت میں داخل نہیں ہو سکتے جب تک ایمان نہ لاؤ، اور ایمان نہیں لا سکتے جب تک ایک دوسرے سے محبت نہ کرو۔" (مسلم)
• رحم کرنے والوں پر رحمان رحم کرتا ہے
• صلہ رحمی شفاعت کا ذریعہ ہے

رشتے توڑنے کی سزا:
• سب سے جلد سزا دیے جانے والے گناہوں میں سے
• "کیا تم نے اگر منہ پھیر لیا تو زمین میں فساد کرو گے اور اپنے رشتے توڑو گے؟" (قرآن 47:22)
• دعائیں قبول نہیں ہوتیں
• نبی کریم ﷺ نے فرمایا: "رشتے توڑنے والا جنت میں داخل نہیں ہوگا۔" (بخاری و مسلم)
• اللہ کی رحمت سے محروم

آپ کے رشتہ دار کون ہیں:
• والدین اور دادا دادی، نانا نانی
• بچے اور پوتے پوتیاں
• بہن بھائی اور ان کے بچے
• چچا، خالہ، پھوپھی، ماموں اور ان کے بچے
• تمام خونی رشتہ دار
• وسیع خاندانی اراکین

رشتے کیسے برقرار رکھیں:
• باقاعدگی سے ملاقات کریں
• فون یا پیغام سے خبر گیری کریں
• خاص مواقع پر تحائف دیں
• ضرورت کے وقت مدد کریں
• کھانے پر بلائیں
• خاندانی اجتماعات میں شرکت کریں
• ان کے لیے دعا کریں
• ان کی غلطیوں کو معاف کریں

सिला रहमी की अहमियत

सिला रहमी इस्लाम में सबसे ज़्यादा ज़ोर दिए गए आमाल में से एक है।

सिला रहमी क्या है:
• लफ़्ज़ी मअना "रहम को जोड़ना" - ख़ूनी रिश्तों को बरक़रार रखना
• रिश्तेदारों से मेहरबानी, मुलाक़ात, मदद और मोहब्बत शामिल है
• तमाम ख़ानदानी अराकीन - क़रीबी और दूर के
• सिर्फ़ उन तक महदूद नहीं जो आपके साथ अच्छे हैं

बड़े सवाब:
• "और अल्लाह से डरो जिसके नाम पर तुम एक दूसरे से मांगते हो, और रहमों से। बेशक अल्लाह तुम पर निगरान है।" (क़ुरआन 4:1)
• उम्र और रिज़्क़ में इज़ाफ़ा
• नबी करीम ﷺ ने फ़रमाया: "जो चाहे कि उसका रिज़्क़ बढ़े और उम्र दराज़ हो, वो सिला रहमी करे।" (बुख़ारी व मुस्लिम)
• माल और औलाद में बरकत
• अचानक मौत से हिफ़ाज़त

जन्नत में दाख़िला:
• सिला रहमी जन्नत का रास्ता है
• नबी करीम ﷺ ने फ़रमाया: "तुम जन्नत में दाख़िल नहीं हो सकते जब तक ईमान न लाओ, और ईमान नहीं ला सकते जब तक एक दूसरे से मोहब्बत न करो।" (मुस्लिम)
• रहम करने वालों पर रहमान रहम करता है
• सिला रहमी शफ़ाअत का ज़रीआ है

रिश्ते तोड़ने की सज़ा:
• सबसे जल्द सज़ा दिए जाने वाले गुनाहों में से
• "क्या तुमने अगर मुंह फेर लिया तो ज़मीन में फ़साद करोगे और अपने रिश्ते तोड़ोगे?" (क़ुरआन 47:22)
• दुआएं क़बूल नहीं होतीं
• नबी करीम ﷺ ने फ़रमाया: "रिश्ते तोड़ने वाला जन्नत में दाख़िल नहीं होगा।" (बुख़ारी व मुस्लिम)
• अल्लाह की रहमत से महरूम

आपके रिश्तेदार कौन हैं:
• वालिदैन और दादा दादी, नाना नानी
• बच्चे और पोते पोतियां
• बहन भाई और उनके बच्चे
• चाचा, ख़ाला, फूफी, मामूं और उनके बच्चे
• तमाम ख़ूनी रिश्तेदार
• वसी ख़ानदानी अराकीन

रिश्ते कैसे बरक़रार रखें:
• बाक़ायदगी से मुलाक़ात करें
• फ़ोन या पैग़ाम से ख़बरगीरी करें
• ख़ास मवाक़े पर तोहफ़े दें
• ज़रूरत के वक़्त मदद करें
• खाने पर बुलाएं
• ख़ानदानी इजतिमाआत में शिरकत करें
• उनके लिए दुआ करें
• उनकी ग़लतियों को माफ़ करें

أهمية صلة الرحم

صلة الرحم من أعظم القربات إلى الله.

فضل صلة الرحم:
• "وَاتَّقُوا اللَّهَ الَّذِي تَسَاءَلُونَ بِهِ وَالْأَرْحَامَ" (سورة النساء: 1)
• قال النبي ﷺ: "من سره أن يبسط له في رزقه، وينسأ له في أثره، فليصل رحمه" (البخاري)
• سبب في زيادة الرزق والعمر
• سبب في دخول الجنة

أجر صلة الرحم:
• البركة في المال والعمر
• محبة الله ورضاه
• القرب من الله يوم القيامة
• دخول الجنة بسلام
• "فَهَلْ عَسَيْتُمْ إِن تَوَلَّيْتُمْ أَن تُفْسِدُوا فِي الْأَرْضِ" (سورة محمد: 22)

كيفية صلة الرحم:
• الزيارة والتواصل
• السؤال عن الأحوال
• المساعدة المالية والمعنوية
• الهدايا والصدقات
• الدعاء للأقارب

الواصل الحقيقي:
• قال النبي ﷺ: "ليس الواصل بالمكافئ، ولكن الواصل الذي إذا قطعت رحمه وصلها" (البخاري)
• يصل من قطعه
• يعفو عمن أساء إليه
• يحسن إلى من أساء

درجات صلة الرحم:
• الواجب: عدم القطيعة
• المستحب: الزيارة والتواصل
• الأكمل: الإحسان والمساعدة
• الأفضل: الصلة مع القطيعة

Dealing with Difficult Relatives

The true test of maintaining family ties is not when everyone is kind and loving, but when relatives are difficult, unappreciative, or even hostile. Islam teaches us to maintain these ties regardless of how others behave, as this is where the greatest reward lies.

The Prophet's Comprehensive Teaching:

A profound Hadith illustrates this beautifully: A man came to the Prophet ﷺ and said: "O Messenger of Allah, I have relatives with whom I try to maintain ties, but they cut me off. I treat them well, but they treat me badly. I am forbearing with them, but they are harsh and rude to me."

The Prophet ﷺ replied: "If you are as you say, it is as if you are putting hot ashes in their mouths. You will continue to have support from Allah against them as long as you continue to do that." (Muslim)

This powerful metaphor means that your good treatment, despite their bad behavior, burns them with regret and shame, and Allah will continuously support you. The reward is not just in the Hereafter, but immediate divine assistance in this life.

Another companion asked: "O Messenger of Allah, I have relatives with whom I try to uphold the ties of kinship but they cut me off, I treat them kindly but they treat me badly, I am good to them but they are bad to me." The Prophet ﷺ said: "If you are as you say, it is as if you are feeding them hot ashes, and you will have a supporter against them from Allah as long as you continue to do that." (Muslim)

Quranic Guidance on Patience and Forbearance:

Allah commands in the Quran: "Repel evil with that which is better. Then you will see that the one with whom you had enmity has become like a devoted friend." (Quran 41:34)

This verse promises that persistent good behavior can transform enemies into friends. It may not happen immediately, but patience and consistency work miracles on human hearts.

"And not equal are the good deed and the bad. Repel evil by that which is best, and thereupon the one whom between you and him is enmity will become as though he was a devoted friend." (Quran 41:34)

"And whoever is patient and forgives - indeed, that is of the matters requiring determination." (Quran 42:43)

Allah acknowledges that this requires tremendous strength and determination. It's not easy, but it's among the most noble of deeds.

"The servants of the Most Merciful are those who walk upon the earth easily, and when the ignorant address them harshly, they say words of peace." (Quran 25:63)

Types of Difficult Relatives and Strategies for Each:

1. The Critical Relative Who Constantly Finds Fault:
Strategy: Don't take criticism personally. Respond with kindness and compliments. "May Allah reward you for your concern." Visit them regularly despite criticism. Make dua for them to see your good intentions.

2. The Jealous Relative Who Can't Celebrate Your Success:
Strategy: Don't boast about achievements in their presence. Include them in your happiness by sharing gifts. Make them feel valued. "Your prayers have helped me succeed." Downplay worldly gains and emphasize spiritual growth.

3. The Toxic Relative Who Spreads Gossip:
Strategy: Never engage in gossip about them in return. "I heard you said something about me. I wanted to clarify directly with you." Kill rumors with kindness. The Prophet ﷺ said: "Whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day should speak good or remain silent." (Bukhari & Muslim)

4. The Demanding Relative With Endless Requests:
Strategy: Help within your capacity. Be honest about your limitations. "I'd love to help, but I can't right now. Here's what I can do instead." Give what you can without resentment. Set clear, kind boundaries.

5. The Abusive Relative Who Causes Real Harm:
Strategy: Maintain the tie from a safe distance. Send gifts and greetings through others. Make dua for them. Seek help from family elders. The Prophet ﷺ said: "Maintaining kinship ties does not mean reciprocating. Rather, it means that if they cut you off, you keep trying to reconnect." (Bukhari)

6. The Ungrateful Relative Who Never Appreciates:
Strategy: Shift your intention from seeking their appreciation to seeking Allah's pleasure. "I'm not doing this for thanks but for Allah." Remember the hadith of hot ashes - their ingratitude harms them, not you.

7. The Competitive Relative Who Sees Everything as a Contest:
Strategy: Refuse to compete. Compliment them genuinely. "MashaAllah, you've done so well!" Make them feel they've won. The real victory is in your noble character.

Prophetic Examples of Dealing with Difficult Relatives:

1. The Prophet's Uncle Abu Lahab:
Despite Abu Lahab's extreme hostility and mockery, the Prophet ﷺ continued attempting reconciliation and inviting him to Islam until his death. He never cursed him or sought revenge.

2. The Prophet's Treatment of Abu Sufyan:
Before Abu Sufyan accepted Islam, he was a chief enemy who organized armies against Muslims. Yet the Prophet ﷺ showed him extraordinary mercy when he finally came to Makkah, honoring his household and forgiving past crimes.

3. Prophet Yusuf (AS) and His Brothers:
After years of separation caused by his brothers' betrayal (throwing him in a well and selling him into slavery), Prophet Yusuf said to them: "No blame will there be upon you today. Allah will forgive you, and He is the Most Merciful of the merciful." (Quran 12:92)

Setting Healthy Boundaries While Maintaining Ties:

Maintaining family ties doesn't mean accepting abuse or enabling destructive behavior. Islam teaches balance:

• You can maintain ties through occasional calls, messages, and gifts without constant physical presence if they're harmful
• The Prophet ﷺ said: "One of you should not wish to be like anyone else except in two cases: a man whom Allah has given wealth and he spends it in the right way, and a man whom Allah has given wisdom and he acts upon it and teaches it to others." (Bukhari)
• Protect your mental health while fulfilling your religious duty
• Involve trusted family mediators when direct contact is too painful
• Send Eid greetings, attend major family events (weddings, funerals) even if you limit regular contact
• Your children have rights too - don't expose them to toxic family members unnecessarily

When They Wrong You - Practical Steps:

1. Process Your Emotions Privately: Feel hurt, but don't react immediately. "When one of you becomes angry while standing, he should sit down. If the anger leaves him, well and good; otherwise he should lie down." (Abu Dawud)

2. Make Dua for Them: "O Allah, guide my family and forgive their mistakes as they don't know the weight of their actions."

3. Respond with Unexpected Kindness: Send them a gift after they've wronged you. This often melts hearts faster than arguments.

4. Seek Understanding: Perhaps they're going through difficulties you don't know about. "Make 70 excuses for your brother." (Bayhaqi)

5. Forgive Quickly: "Those who restrain anger and who pardon people - Allah loves the doers of good." (Quran 3:134)

6. Don't Broadcast Their Faults: Protect their dignity as you wish Allah to protect yours.

Psychological Aspects and Emotional Intelligence:

Understanding human psychology helps in dealing with difficult relatives:

• Hurt people hurt people: Often, difficult behavior stems from their own pain, insecurity, or past trauma
• Projection: They may criticize in you what they dislike in themselves
• Attention-seeking: Negative attention is still attention for those who feel neglected
• Cultural conditioning: They may not know better based on how they were raised
• Mental health issues: Undiagnosed depression, anxiety, or personality disorders can manifest as difficult behavior

Emotional Intelligence in Family Dealings:

1. Self-awareness: Recognize your own triggers and emotional patterns
2. Self-regulation: Control your reactions even when provoked
3. Empathy: Try to understand their perspective and pain
4. Social skills: Communicate assertively but kindly
5. Motivation: Remember your higher purpose - Allah's pleasure

The Unique Reward for Patience with Difficult Relatives:

The Prophet ﷺ said: "The one who maintains family ties is not the one who reciprocates good treatment. Rather, the one who maintains family ties is the one who, when his relatives cut him off, maintains ties with them." (Bukhari)

This Hadith revolutionizes our understanding. True silat ar-rahm is demonstrated when it's difficult, not when it's easy.

"Indeed, the patient will be given their reward without account." (Quran 39:10) - unlimited reward for unlimited patience.

Modern Application - Technology and Distance:

Today's world offers new ways to maintain ties despite difficult dynamics:

• Video calls reduce the need for extended stressful visits while maintaining visual connection
• Messages allow you to reach out without immediate confrontation
• Social media lets you acknowledge their life events with a simple like or comment
• Digital gift cards make gift-giving easy across distances
• Group family chats let you participate without one-on-one pressure

Financial Wisdom When Money Creates Conflict:

"And if someone is in hardship, then let there be postponement until a time of ease. But if you give from your right as charity, it is better for you, if you only knew." (Quran 2:280)

• Never lend money you can't afford to lose to family
• If they owe you money and are struggling, consider forgiving it entirely
• Don't let them know if you're forgiving the debt to avoid hurting their pride
• The Prophet ﷺ said: "Whoever would like Allah to save him from the hardships of the Day of Resurrection, let him give more time to his debtor who is in difficulty, or let him write off the debt." (Muslim)
• Don't use money as leverage or to manipulate family members

The Ultimate Perspective - Why Continue Despite Difficulty:

1. Allah's Command: It's not about whether they deserve it, but about obeying Allah

2. Your Own Soul's Purity: Maintaining good character despite mistreatment purifies your heart from resentment

3. Setting an Example: Your children learn from your behavior toward extended family

4. Unknown Future: The difficult relative today might be your greatest supporter tomorrow

5. Day of Judgment: You'll be asked about your duties, not about whether they reciprocated

6. Blessings in Life: "Whoever would like his provision to be increased and his lifespan to be extended, let him maintain the ties of kinship." (Bukhari & Muslim)

A Final Word of Encouragement:

The scholars say: "If they are harsh to you, be gentle with them. If they cut you off, connect with them. If they wrong you, forgive them. If they're ungrateful, be patient. Soon, either their hearts will soften, or yours will be elevated in Paradise, or both."

Remember: Your good character is YOUR jannah being built brick by brick, regardless of anyone else's behavior. Every time you choose kindness over retaliation, you're making an investment in eternal success.

"So be patient. Indeed, the promise of Allah is truth. And ask forgiveness for your sin and exalt Allah with praise of your Lord in the evening and the morning." (Quran 40:55)

مشکل رشتہ داروں سے نمٹنا

رشتے برقرار رکھنے کا اصل امتحان اس وقت ہوتا ہے جب رشتہ دار مشکل ہوں۔

نبی کریم ﷺ کی تعلیم:
• ایک آدمی نبی کریم ﷺ کے پاس آیا اور کہا: "میرے رشتہ دار ہیں جن سے میں رشتہ برقرار رکھنے کی کوشش کرتا ہوں، لیکن وہ مجھے کاٹ دیتے ہیں۔ میں ان کے ساتھ اچھا سلوک کرتا ہوں، لیکن وہ میرے ساتھ برا سلوک کرتے ہیں۔ میں ان کے ساتھ نرم ہوں، لیکن وہ مجھ پر سخت ہیں۔"
• نبی کریم ﷺ نے فرمایا: "اگر تم جیسا کہتے ہو ویسے ہو، تو یہ ایسے ہے جیسے تم ان کے منہ میں گرم راکھ ڈال رہے ہو۔ اللہ تمہاری مدد جاری رکھے گا جب تک تم یہ کرتے رہو۔" (مسلم)

صبر کلیدی ہے:
• برائی کا جواب برائی سے نہ دیں
• "برائی کو اس چیز سے دور کرو جو بہتر ہے۔" (قرآن 41:34)
• بدسلوکی کے باوجود مہربانی جاری رکھیں
• یاد رکھیں ثواب اللہ کے پاس ہے
• آپ کا اچھا کردار آخرکار دل جیت لے گا

جب وہ آپ پر ظلم کریں:
• ان کی غلطیوں کو معاف کریں
• بدلہ نہ لیں
• ان کی ہدایت کے لیے دعا کریں
• رابطہ کھلا رکھیں
• ضرورت ہو تو حدود مقرر کریں
• دوسروں سے ان کی غیبت نہ کریں

جب وہ آپ کو کاٹ دیں:
• بدلے میں انہیں نہ کاٹیں
• وقتاً فوقتاً رابطہ کرتے رہیں
• دوسروں کے ذریعے سلام بھیجیں
• ان کے لیے دعا کریں
• مناسب ہو تو تحائف دیں
• صلح کے لیے پہل کریں

مالی مسائل:
• اگر وہ آپ کے مقروض ہیں تو صبر کریں
• سختی سے مطالبہ نہ کریں
• اگر وہ مشکل میں ہیں تو قرض معاف کرنے پر غور کریں
• پیسے کو رشتوں کو تباہ نہ کرنے دیں
• "اور اگر کوئی تنگ دست ہے تو آسانی تک مہلت دی جائے۔" (قرآن 2:280)

اپنے حقوق کی حفاظت:
• رشتے برقرار رکھتے ہوئے اپنی حفاظت کر سکتے ہیں
• صحت مند حدود مقرر کریں
• بری عادتوں کو فروغ نہ دیں
• دانشمند لوگوں سے مشورہ لیں
• ضرورت ہو تو بزرگوں کو بیچ میں لائیں
• اگر وہ آپ کے ایمان کے لیے نقصان دہ ہیں تو فاصلہ بنائیں

یاد رکھیں:
• آپ کا ثواب آپ کی کوشش کے لیے ہے، ان کے جواب کے لیے نہیں
• اللہ آپ کی خلوص دیکھتا ہے
• ناقص انسانوں سے کمال کی توقع نہ رکھیں
• اللہ کو خوش کرنے پر توجہ دیں، انہیں نہیں
• جتنا مشکل ہوگا، ثواب اتنا زیادہ ہوگا

• एक आदमी नबी करीम ﷺ के पास आया और कहा: "मेरे रिश्तेदार हैं जिनसे मैं रिश्ता बरक़रार रखने की कोशिश करता हूं, लेकिन वो मुझे काट देते हैं। मैं उनके साथ अच्छा सुलूक करता हूं, लेकिन वो मेरे साथ बुरा सुलूक करते हैं। मैं उनके साथ नरम हूं, लेकिन वो मुझ पर सख़्त हैं।"
• नबी करीम ﷺ ने फ़रमाया: "अगर तुम जैसा कहते हो वैसे हो, तो यह ऐसे है जैसे तुम उनके मुंह में गरम राख डाल रहे हो। अल्लाह तुम्हारी मदद जारी रखेगा जब तक तुम यह करते रहो।" (मुस्लिम)

सब्र कुंजी है:
• बुराई का जवाब बुराई से न दें
• "बुराई को उस चीज़ से दूर करो जो बेहतर है।" (क़ुरआन 41:34)
• बदसुलूकी के बावजूद मेहरबानी जारी रखें
• याद रखें सवाब अल्लाह के पास है
• आपका अच्छा किरदार आख़िरकार दिल जीत लेगा

जब वो आप पर ज़ुल्म करें:
• उनकी ग़लतियों को माफ़ करें
• बदला न लें
• उनकी हिदायत के लिए दुआ करें
• राबिता खुला रखें
• ज़रूरत हो तो हुदूद मुक़र्रर करें
• दूसरों से उनकी ग़ीबत न करें

जब वो आपको काट दें:
• बदले में उन्हें न काटें
• वक़्तन फ़ौक़्तन राबिता करते रहें
• दूसरों के ज़रीए सलाम भेजें
• उनके लिए दुआ करें
• मुनासिब हो तो तोहफ़े दें
• सुलह के लिए पहल करें

माली मसाइल:
• अगर वो आपके मक़रूज़ हैं तो सब्र करें
• सख़्ती से मुतालबा न करें
• अगर वो मुश्किल में हैं तो क़र्ज़ माफ़ करने पर ग़ौर करें
• पैसे को रिश्तों को तबाह न करने दें
• "और अगर कोई तंगदस्त है तो आसानी तक मोहलत दी जाए।" (क़ुरआन 2:280)

अपने हुक़ूक़ की हिफ़ाज़त:
• रिश्ते बरक़रार रखते हुए अपनी हिफ़ाज़त कर सकते हैं
• सेहतमंद हुदूद मुक़र्रर करें
• बुरी आदतों को फ़रोग़ न दें
• दानिशमंद लोगों से मशवरा लें
• ज़रूरत हो तो बुज़ुर्गों को बीच में लाएं
• अगर वो आपके ईमान के लिए नुक़सानदेह हैं तो फ़ासला बनाएं

याद रखें:
• आपका सवाब आपकी कोशिश के लिए है, उनके जवाब के लिए नहीं
• अल्लाह आपकी ख़ुलूस देखता है
• नाक़िस इंसानों से कमाल की तवक़्क़ो न रखें
• अल्लाह को ख़ुश करने पर तवज्जोह दें, उन्हें नहीं
• जितना मुश्किल होगा, सवाब उतना ज़्यादा होगा

Neighbors as Extended Family - Complete Rights and Responsibilities

In Islam, neighbors hold such a special status that they are considered nearly as important as blood relatives. The emphasis on neighborly rights is so profound that it forms a cornerstone of Islamic social ethics and community building.

The Supreme Status of Neighbors in Islam:

Allah places the rights of neighbors immediately after the rights of parents and relatives in the Quran:

"Worship Allah and associate nothing with Him, and to parents do good, and to relatives, orphans, the needy, the near neighbor, the neighbor farther away, the companion at your side, the traveler, and those whom your right hands possess. Indeed, Allah does not like those who are self-deluding and boastful." (Quran 4:36)

Notice how Allah categorizes neighbors into two types:
1. "The near neighbor" (Al-Jar dhal-Qurba) - the close neighbor
2. "The neighbor farther away" (Al-Jar al-Junub) - the distant neighbor

Both have rights upon you, with the closer neighbor having greater rights.

The Prophet's Unprecedented Emphasis:

The Prophet Muhammad ﷺ said: "Jibreel kept advising me about the neighbor until I thought he would make him an heir." (Bukhari & Muslim)

This powerful statement shows that the angel Jibreel repeatedly emphasized the rights of neighbors to the Prophet ﷺ, to the point where the Prophet thought neighbors might be given inheritance rights like family members!

Another Hadith states: "By Allah, he does not believe! By Allah, he does not believe! By Allah, he does not believe!" It was said, "Who, O Messenger of Allah?" He said: "The one whose neighbor is not safe from his harm." (Bukhari)

The repetition three times shows the gravity of harming neighbors and that such a person's faith is deficient.

The Complete Levels of Neighbors and Their Rights:

Islamic scholars have identified three distinct levels of neighbors, each with cumulative rights:

Level 1: The Muslim Neighbor Who is Also a Relative
This neighbor has three rights:
• The right of Islam (being a fellow Muslim)
• The right of kinship (being a blood relative)
• The right of being a neighbor (living nearby)
This is the neighbor with the most rights, deserving the highest priority in kindness, help, and consideration.

Level 2: The Muslim Neighbor
This neighbor has two rights:
• The right of Islam
• The right of being a neighbor
All Muslim neighbors deserve good treatment, visiting when sick, congratulations in joy, and help in times of need.

Level 3: The Non-Muslim Neighbor
This neighbor has:
• The right of being a neighbor
Islam commands kindness to all neighbors regardless of their religion. The Prophet ﷺ had Jewish neighbors in Madinah whom he treated with respect and kindness. This is a beautiful example of Islam's universal values of compassion and coexistence.

Who Exactly is Considered Your Neighbor?

The scholars have differed on the precise definition:
• Some say: 40 houses in each direction (front, back, left, right)
• Some say: Everyone within hearing distance if you called for help
• Some say: Everyone on your street or in your building
• The most practical definition: Anyone whose proximity to you gives you regular contact or influence over their wellbeing

The Comprehensive Rights of Neighbors - 15+ Authentic Hadith:

1. Protection from All Forms of Harm:

The Prophet ﷺ said: "Whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day, let him not harm his neighbor." (Bukhari & Muslim)

This includes:
• Physical harm: No violence, aggression, or physical intimidation
• Verbal harm: No insults, gossip, backbiting, or harsh words
• Visual harm: No looking into their windows or invading their privacy
• Auditory harm: No excessive noise, loud music, or disturbances
• Olfactory harm: No bad smells from garbage or cooking that disturb them
• Property harm: No encroachment on their property, blocking their driveway, or damaging their belongings
• Environmental harm: No polluting shared spaces or creating unsightly conditions

2. Patience with Their Harm:

The Prophet ﷺ said: "The best companion in the sight of Allah is the one who is best to his companion, and the best neighbor in the sight of Allah is the one who is best to his neighbor." (Tirmidhi - Sahih)

Even when neighbors are difficult, Islam teaches patience and continued good treatment. Don't respond to harm with harm.

3. Sharing Food and Provisions:

The Prophet ﷺ said: "He is not a believer whose stomach is filled while his neighbor goes hungry." (Bayhaqi - Authenticated by Al-Albani)

The Prophet ﷺ also said: "O Abu Dharr, when you make broth, add extra water to it and give some to your neighbors." (Muslim)

Abdullah ibn Amr reported: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: "The best companion with Allah is the best to his companions, and the best neighbor with Allah is the best to his neighbors." (Tirmidhi - Sahih)

The Prophet ﷺ said: "He is not a true believer who fills his stomach while his neighbor is hungry." (Bayhaqi - Authenticated)

4. Visiting When Sick:

The Prophet ﷺ said: "Whoever visits a sick person is plunging into mercy until he sits down, and when he sits down he becomes submerged in it." (Ahmad - Sahih)

5. Congratulating in Times of Joy:

The Prophet ﷺ said: "Give gifts to one another and you will love one another." (Al-Adab Al-Mufrad - Sahih)

6. Offering Condolences in Times of Grief:

The Prophet ﷺ said: "Whoever consoles a person afflicted with a calamity will have a reward similar to his." (Tirmidhi - Hasan)

7. Concealing Their Faults and Protecting Their Honor:

The Prophet ﷺ said: "Whoever conceals the faults of a Muslim, Allah will conceal his faults in this world and the Hereafter." (Muslim)

8. Helping in Times of Need:

The Prophet ﷺ said: "Whoever relieves a Muslim of a burden from the burdens of the world, Allah will relieve him of a burden from the burdens on the Day of Resurrection." (Muslim)

The Severe Warning About Bad Neighbors:

A woman asked the Prophet ﷺ: "O Messenger of Allah, so-and-so prays at night, fasts during the day, performs obligatory acts of worship, and gives charity, but she harms her neighbors with her tongue." The Prophet ﷺ said: "There is no good in her; she is from the people of Hell." (Ahmad - Authenticated)

Then she mentioned another woman: "O Messenger of Allah, so-and-so prays the prescribed prayers and gives charity of leftover yogurt, but she does not harm anyone." He said: "She is from the people of Paradise." (Ahmad - Authenticated)

The Prophet ﷺ said: "Do you know what the rights of a neighbor are? If he asks for your help, you help him. If he asks you for a loan, you give him a loan. If he becomes poor, you provide for him. If he becomes ill, you visit him. If something good happens to him, you congratulate him. If a calamity befalls him, you console him. If he dies, you follow his funeral." (Al-Adab Al-Mufrad by Bukhari - Sahih)

The Prophet ﷺ said: "Jibreel continued to advise me concerning the neighbor to such an extent that I thought he would order me to make him an heir." (Bukhari & Muslim)

The Prophet ﷺ said: "He will not enter Paradise whose neighbor is not secure from his wrongful conduct." (Muslim)

The Prophet ﷺ said: "A man may perform the prayer, observe the fast, give charity, and perform Hajj and Umrah, yet he will not receive a reward for it. It was said: Why, O Messenger of Allah? He said: Because he treats people with bad character." (Tabarani - Hasan)

The Prophet ﷺ said: "The neighbor has the most right to being treated well." (Bukhari)

Qualities of a Good Neighbor:

1. Greeting with Peace:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "You will not enter Paradise until you believe, and you will not believe until you love one another. Shall I tell you something that, if you do it, you will love one another? Spread peace (salaam) among yourselves." (Muslim)

2. Respecting Privacy:
"O you who believe! Do not enter houses other than your own until you ascertain welcome and greet their inhabitants." (Quran 24:27)

3. Lending and Sharing:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "Whoever lends something twice, it is as if he has given it in charity once." (Ibn Majah - Sahih)

Prophetic Examples of Neighborly Love:

1. The Prophet's Jewish Neighbor:
The Prophet ﷺ had a Jewish neighbor in Madinah who used to throw garbage at his door daily. The Prophet never complained. One day, when the garbage wasn't there, the Prophet inquired and learned his neighbor was sick. He visited him, and the neighbor was so moved by this kindness that he embraced Islam.

2. The Prophet's Advice to Abu Dharr:
The Prophet ﷺ specifically told Abu Dharr: "When you cook soup, add extra water and share it with your neighbors." (Muslim)

3. The Prophet's Gift-Giving:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "Do not belittle any good deed, even meeting your brother with a cheerful face." (Muslim)

Modern Neighborhood Challenges and Islamic Solutions:

Challenge 1: Anonymous Urban Living
Solution: Actively introduce yourself. Knock on doors with a gift. Organize building or street gatherings.

Challenge 2: Cultural and Religious Diversity
Solution: Islamic teachings apply to all neighbors regardless of faith. Be the best representative of Islam through your character.

Challenge 3: Privacy vs. Community
Solution: Respect boundaries while being available. A simple greeting doesn't invade privacy but builds connection.

Challenge 4: Digital Disconnection
Solution: Create neighborhood WhatsApp groups for sharing information and helping each other.

Challenge 5: Busy Lifestyles
Solution: Small gestures matter. Even a 2-minute conversation when you see them shows care.

Challenge 6: Parking and Space Disputes
Solution: Be flexible and accommodating. The Prophet ﷺ said: "Make things easy and do not make them difficult." (Bukhari)

Practical Action Plan for Being a Better Neighbor:

Week 1: Introduce yourself if you haven't already. Share some homemade food or fruits.
Week 2: Exchange phone numbers. Offer specific help.
Week 3: Learn about their family, culture, and needs.
Week 4: Organize a small neighborhood gathering.

Ongoing: Maintain regular small gestures - greetings, occasional food sharing, checking on them, helping when needed.

Building Community Through Islamic Neighborly Values:

1. Organize Neighborhood Gatherings
2. Establish Neighborhood Watch Programs
3. Help Elderly and Disabled Neighbors
4. Create Safe Spaces for Children
5. Collaborate on Neighborhood Improvements
6. Resolve Conflicts Peacefully

Conclusion - Neighbors as Extended Family:

The Prophet ﷺ said: "Gabriel continued to advise me about the neighbor to the point that I thought he would inherit from him." (Agreed upon)

Your neighbor has nearly the status of a family member who would inherit from you. This is how important they are in Islam. When you understand this, you'll never see your neighborhood the same way again.

پڑوسی - وسیع خاندان کی طرح

اسلام نے پڑوسیوں کے حقوق پر بہت زور دیا ہے۔

پڑوسیوں کا مقام:
• "اللہ کی عبادت کرو اور اس کے ساتھ کسی کو شریک نہ ٹھہراؤ، اور والدین کے ساتھ اچھا سلوک کرو اور رشتہ داروں، یتیموں، محتاجوں اور قریبی پڑوسی اور دور کے پڑوسی کے ساتھ۔" (قرآن 4:36)
• نبی کریم ﷺ نے فرمایا: "جبریل مجھے پڑوسی کے بارے میں نصیحت کرتے رہے یہاں تک کہ میں نے سوچا کہ وہ اسے وارث بنا دیں گے۔" (بخاری و مسلم)
• پڑوسیوں کے رشتہ داروں جیسے حقوق ہیں

تین قسمیں:
1. مسلمان پڑوسی جو رشتہ دار بھی ہے - تین حقوق: اسلام کا حق، رشتہ داری کا حق، اور پڑ��سی ہونے کا حق
2. مسلمان پڑوسی - دو حقوق: اسلام کا حق اور پڑوسی ہونے کا حق
3. غیر مسلم پڑوسی - پڑوسی ہونے کا حق

• کسی بھی طرح سے انہیں نقصان نہ پہنچائیں
• ان کے نقصان پر صبر کریں
• ان کے ساتھ کھانا بانٹیں
• نبی کریم ﷺ نے فرمایا: "وہ مومن نہیں جو پیٹ بھر کر کھائے جبکہ اس کا پڑوسی بھوکا ہو۔" (بیہقی)

• غم کے وقت تعزیت کریں

• ان کے گھروں میں جھانکنا نہیں
• شور کی سطح کم رکھنا

برے پڑوسی کی تنبیہ:

• پڑوسیوں کے ساتھ آپ کا سلوک آپ کے ایمان کی عکاسی کرتا ہے

عملی قدم:

पड़ोसी - वसी ख़ानदान की तरह

इस्लाम ने पड़ोसियों के हुक़ूक़ पर बहुत ज़ोर दिया है।

पड़ोसियों का मक़ाम:
• "अल्लाह की इबादत करो और उसके साथ किसी को शरीक न ठहराओ, और वालिदैन के साथ अच्छा सुलूक करो और रिश्तेदारों, यतीमों, मोहताजों और क़रीबी पड़ोसी और दूर के पड़ोसी के साथ।" (क़ुरआन 4:36)
• नबी करीम ﷺ ने फ़रमाया: "जिबरील मुझे पड़ोसी के बारे में नसीहत करते रहे यहां तक कि मैंने सोचा कि वो उसे वारिस बना देंगे।" (बुख़ारी व मुस्लिम)
• पड़ोसियों के रिश्तेदारों जैसे हुक़ूक़ हैं

तीन क़िस्में:
1. मुसलमान पड़ोसी जो रिश्तेदार भी है - तीन हुक़ूक़: इस्लाम का हक़, रिश्तेदारी का हक़, और पड़ोसी होने का हक़
2. मुसलमान पड़ोसी - दो हुक़ूक़: इस्लाम का हक़ और पड़ोसी होने का हक़
3. ग़ैर मुस्लिम पड़ोसी - पड़ोसी होने का हक़

पड़ोसियों के हुक़ूक़:
• किसी भी तरह से उन्हें नुक़सान न पहुंचाएं
• उनके नुक़सान पर सब्र करें
• उनके साथ खाना बांटें
• नबी करीम ﷺ ने फ़रमाया: "वो मोमिन नहीं जो पेट भरकर खाए जबकि उसका पड़ोसी भूखा हो।" (बैहक़ी)
• ज़रूरत के वक़्त मदद करें
• बीमारी में मुलाक़ात करें
• ख़ुशी के मौक़े पर मुबारकबाद दें
• ग़म के वक़्त ताज़ियत करें

अच्छे पड़ोसी की ख़ुसूसियात:
• सलाम के साथ मुलाक़ात
• निगाह झुकाना और राज़दारी का एहतराम
• उनके घरों में झांकना नहीं
• शोर की सतह कम रखना
• उनके रास्ते में रुकावट न डालना
• फल और अच्छी चीज़ें बांटना
• ज़रूरत पड़ने पर चीज़ें उधार देना

बुरे पड़ोसी की तंबीह:
• एक औरत ने पूछा: "ऐ अल्लाह के रसूल, फ़लां औरत रात को नमाज़ पढ़ती है, दिन में रोज़ा रखती है, नेक काम करती है और सदक़ा देती है, लेकिन वो अपनी ज़बान से अपने पड़ोसियों को तकलीफ़ देती है।" आपने फ़रमाया: "वो जहन्नम में है।" (अहमद)
• अच्छी इबादत पड़ोसियों के साथ बुरे सुलूक का बहाना नहीं बनती
• पड़ोसियों के साथ आपका सुलूक आपके ईमान की अक्कासी करता है

अमली क़दम:
• नए पड़ोसियों से अपना तआरुफ़ कराएं
• फ़ोन नंबर तबदील करें
• फ़ेअल तौर पर मदद की पेशकश करें
• उन्हें खाने पर बुलाएं
• अपनी बरकतें बांटें
• हंगामी हालात में मौजूद रहें
• कम्युनिटी के बंधन बनाएं

कम्युनिटी बनाना:
• मोहल्ले के इजतिमाआत का एहतमाम करें
• निगरानी के प्रोग्राम क़ायम करें

• मोहल्ले की बेहतरी पर तआवुन करें

Muslim Brotherhood (Ukhuwwah) - The Bond That Transcends All Boundaries

The concept of Islamic brotherhood (Ukhuwwah) is one of the most beautiful and revolutionary teachings of Islam. It created a social structure where people of different races, tribes, nations, and backgrounds became one family united by faith.

The Divine Declaration of Brotherhood:

Allah says in the Quran: "The believers are but brothers, so make settlement between your brothers. And fear Allah that you may receive mercy." (Quran 49:10)

This verse establishes that all believers, regardless of ethnicity, language, or nationality, are brothers and sisters in Islam. This brotherhood is not metaphorical—it carries real rights and responsibilities.

"And hold firmly to the rope of Allah all together and do not become divided. And remember the favor of Allah upon you - when you were enemies and He brought your hearts together and you became, by His favor, brothers." (Quran 3:103)

This verse reminds us how Islam transformed sworn enemies into beloved brothers. The tribes of Aws and Khazraj in Madinah had been in conflict for generations, but Islam united them as Ansar (helpers).

The Historic Brotherhood Between Muhajireen and Ansar:

When the Prophet ﷺ migrated to Madinah, he established a formal bond of brotherhood between the Muhajireen (migrants from Makkah) and the Ansar (helpers from Madinah). This wasn't just symbolic:

• The Ansar shared their homes with the Muhajireen
• They divided their wealth equally
• Some even offered to divorce one of their wives so their Muhajir brother could marry
• They gave half their date palm trees and property
• They treated each other as actual blood brothers

This practical demonstration of brotherhood transformed society and showed the world what true Islamic unity means.

The Prophet's Powerful Descriptions of Brotherhood:

1. The Body Analogy:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "The example of the believers in their affection, mercy, and compassion for each other is that of a body. When any limb aches, the whole body reacts with sleeplessness and fever." (Bukhari & Muslim)

This means: When one Muslim suffers anywhere in the world, all Muslims should feel that pain and respond to help.

2. The Building Analogy:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "The believer to another believer is like a building whose different parts support each other." Then he ﷺ clasped his hands with the fingers interlaced. (Bukhari & Muslim)

Muslims should support, strengthen, and hold each other up like bricks in a wall.

3. The Mirror Analogy:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "The believer is a mirror to his brother. The believer is the brother of a believer; he protects him from ruin and guards his back." (Abu Dawud - Sahih)

A true brother shows you your faults privately (like a mirror), protects your reputation, and defends you in your absence.

The Complete Rights of Muslims Upon Each Other - 15+ Authentic Hadith:

1. Returning the Greeting of Peace:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "The rights of one Muslim over another are six." He was asked: "What are they, O Messenger of Allah?" He said: "When you meet him, greet him with peace; when he invites you, respond to his invitation; when he seeks your advice, advise him; when he sneezes and praises Allah, say 'Yarhamuk Allah' (may Allah have mercy on you); when he falls ill, visit him; and when he dies, follow his funeral." (Muslim)

2. Helping Fellow Muslims:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "Whoever fulfills the needs of his brother, Allah will fulfill his needs. Whoever removes a worldly hardship from a believer, Allah will remove from him one of the hardships of the Day of Resurrection." (Bukhari & Muslim)

3. Loving Them for Allah's Sake:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "The strongest bond of faith is to love for the sake of Allah and to hate for the sake of Allah." (Abu Dawud - Sahih)

The Prophet ﷺ also said: "On the Day of Resurrection, Allah will say: 'Where are those who loved each other for My glory? Today I will shade them in My shade on the day when there is no shade but Mine.'" (Muslim)

4. Advising Sincerely:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "Religion is sincerity." We said: "To whom?" He said: "To Allah, His Book, His Messenger, and to the leaders of the Muslims and their common folk." (Muslim)

5. Not Harming Them:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "A Muslim is a brother of another Muslim. He does not wrong him, nor does he forsake him, nor does he lie to him, nor does he hold him in contempt." (Muslim)

6. Visiting the Sick:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "Feed the hungry, visit the sick, and free the captives." (Bukhari)

The Prophet ﷺ said: "When a Muslim visits his sick Muslim brother in the morning, seventy thousand angels make dua for him until the evening. And when he visits him in the evening, seventy thousand angels make dua for him until the morning, and he will be granted a garden in Paradise." (Tirmidhi - Hasan)

7. Attending Funerals:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "Whoever follows the funeral procession until he offers the funeral prayer for it, will get a reward equal to one Qirat, and whoever accompanies it till burial, will get a reward equal to two Qirats." Someone asked, "What are two Qirats?" He replied, "Like two huge mountains." (Bukhari & Muslim)

8. Accepting Invitations:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "If any of you is invited, let him accept the invitation." (Muslim)

9. Praying for Them in Their Absence:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "The supplication of a Muslim for his brother in his absence will certainly be answered. Every time he makes a supplication for good for his brother, the angel appointed for this particular task says: 'Ameen! May it be for you, too.'" (Muslim)

10. Concealing Their Faults:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "Whoever conceals the faults of a Muslim, Allah will conceal his faults in this world and the Hereafter." (Muslim)

11. Defending Their Honor:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "Whoever defends the honor of his brother, Allah will protect his face from the Fire on the Day of Resurrection." (Tirmidhi - Sahih)

12. Forgiving Their Mistakes:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "Do not hate one another, do not envy one another, do not turn away from one another, but be servants of Allah as brothers. It is not permissible for a Muslim to forsake his brother for more than three days." (Bukhari & Muslim)

13. Being Trustworthy:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "The signs of a hypocrite are three: when he speaks, he lies; when he makes a promise, he breaks it; and when he is entrusted with something, he betrays that trust." (Bukhari & Muslim)

14. Helping in Righteousness:
"And cooperate in righteousness and piety, but do not cooperate in sin and aggression. And fear Allah; indeed, Allah is severe in penalty." (Quran 5:2)

15. Wishing Good for Them:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "None of you truly believes until he loves for his brother what he loves for himself." (Bukhari & Muslim)

What Breaks and Weakens Brotherhood - What to Avoid:

1. Envy and Jealousy:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "Beware of envy because envy consumes good deeds just as fire consumes wood or grass." (Abu Dawud - Sahih)

2. Spying and Suspicion:
"O you who have believed, avoid much [negative] assumption. Indeed, some assumption is sin. And do not spy or backbite each other." (Quran 49:12)

The Prophet ﷺ said: "Beware of suspicion, for suspicion is the worst of false tales." (Bukhari & Muslim)

3. Backbiting and Gossip:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "Do you know what backbiting is?" They said: "Allah and His Messenger know best." He said: "It is to mention your brother in a way he dislikes." (Muslim)

4. Hatred and Hostility:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "Do not hate one another, do not envy one another, do not turn away from one another, but be servants of Allah as brothers." (Muslim)

5. Breaking Promises:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "The signs of a hypocrite are three: when he speaks, he lies; when he makes a promise, he breaks it; and when he is entrusted with something, he betrays that trust." (Bukhari & Muslim)

6. Rejoicing at Their Misfortune:
The Prophet ﷺ warned against this behavior. Instead, we should feel sympathy and offer help.

7. Competing in Worldly Matters:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "There is no envy except in two cases: a person whom Allah has given wealth and he spends it in the right way, and a person whom Allah has given wisdom and he acts upon it and teaches it to others." (Bukhari & Muslim)

Loving for Allah's Sake - The Highest Form of Love:

The Prophet ﷺ said: "Seven people will be shaded by Allah on the Day when there will be no shade except His. Among them are: a just ruler, a young person who grew up in the worship of Allah, a man whose heart is attached to the mosque, two people who love each other for the sake of Allah—meeting for that purpose and parting upon it..." (Bukhari & Muslim)

This is the purest form of love—loving someone not for their wealth, status, beauty, or benefit to you, but purely because they help you get closer to Allah.

The Prophet ﷺ said: "A man set out to visit a brother in another town. Allah sent an angel to wait for him on the road. When the man came along, the angel asked: 'Where are you going?' He said: 'I am going to visit my brother in this town.' The angel said: 'Have you done any favor for him?' He said: 'No, except that I love him for the sake of Allah.' The angel said: 'I am a messenger to you from Allah to tell you that Allah loves you as you have loved your brother for His sake.'" (Muslim)

Practical Ways to Build and Strengthen Brotherhood:

1. Regular Gatherings for Dhikr:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "No people gather together in one of the houses of Allah, reciting the Book of Allah and studying it together, except that tranquility descends upon them, mercy covers them, angels surround them, and Allah mentions them amongst those who are with Him." (Muslim)

2. Sharing Meals Together:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "O people! Spread peace, feed the hungry, and pray at night when people are sleeping, and you will enter Paradise in peace." (Tirmidhi - Sahih)

3. Exchanging Gifts:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "Give gifts to one another and you will love one another." (Al-Adab Al-Mufrad - Sahih)

4. Visiting One Another:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "Whoever visits a sick person or visits a brother in faith, a caller announces: 'You are blessed, your walking is blessed, and you have made a dwelling in Paradise.'" (Tirmidhi - Hasan)

5. Making Dua for Each Other:
Make sincere prayers for your brothers and sisters in their absence. The angels say "Ameen, and for you the same."

6. Helping in Times of Need:
Be the first to help when a brother faces difficulty—financial, emotional, or spiritual.

7. Celebrating Joys Together:
Share in their happiness at weddings, births, achievements, and good news.

8. Consoling in Sorrows:
Be present during their difficulties, losses, and trials.

Unity of the Ummah - Preserving Brotherhood on a Global Scale:

"And hold firmly to the rope of Allah all together and do not become divided." (Quran 3:103)

The Prophet ﷺ said: "The believers, in their mutual love, mercy, and compassion, are like one body. If one part of it complains, the rest of the body responds with wakefulness and fever." (Bukhari & Muslim)

Modern Applications of Islamic Brotherhood:

1. Supporting Muslim Communities Globally:
Feel the pain of Muslims facing hardship anywhere in the world and help through charity, advocacy, and dua.

2. Building Local Muslim Communities:
Create strong bonds with Muslims in your mosque, school, and neighborhood.

3. Mentorship and Youth Development:
Older Muslims should mentor younger ones, strengthening generational bonds.

4. Professional Networking:
Help fellow Muslims find jobs, business opportunities, and career growth.

5. Marriage and Family Support:
Help single Muslims find spouses and support families in need.

6. Educational Support:
Share knowledge, tutor students, and help with scholarships.

7. Digital Brotherhood:
Use technology to stay connected, share knowledge, and support each other online while maintaining Islamic etiquette.

The Ultimate Goal - Paradise Together:

The Prophet ﷺ said: "A man will be with those whom he loves." (Bukhari & Muslim)

When a man asked the Prophet ﷺ about the Hour, the Prophet asked: "What have you prepared for it?" He said: "Nothing, except that I love Allah and His Messenger." The Prophet ﷺ said: "You will be with those whom you love." (Bukhari & Muslim)

Anas (the narrator) said: "We have never been more pleased than when the Prophet ﷺ said: 'You will be with those whom you love.' I love the Prophet, Abu Bakr, and Umar, and I hope that I will be with them because of my love for them, even though I have not done deeds like theirs."

Conclusion - The Strength of Muslim Brotherhood:

Islamic brotherhood is not just a nice idea—it's a practical system that, when implemented, creates the strongest, most compassionate, and most resilient communities on earth. It transforms strangers into family, weakness into strength, and isolation into belonging.

The Prophet ﷺ said: "The believer is to another believer like a building whose parts support each other." (Bukhari & Muslim)

When Muslims truly understand and practice Ukhuwwah, they become unstoppable in goodness, mercy, and positive impact on the world.

Inheritance & Family Wealth - The Divine System of Justice

Islamic inheritance law (Ilm al-Faraid) is one of the most detailed and sophisticated aspects of Islamic jurisprudence. Unlike human-made systems that change with time and culture, Islamic inheritance laws are fixed by Allah Himself, ensuring perfect justice for all family members across all times and places.

The Divine Command - Allah's Direct Legislation:

"For men is a share of what the parents and close relatives leave, and for women is a share of what the parents and close relatives leave, be it little or much—an obligatory share." (Quran 4:7)

This verse revolutionized inheritance by:
• Guaranteeing women's right to inherit (unprecedented in pre-Islamic Arabia)
• Making inheritance obligatory, not optional
• Ensuring both rich and poor families distribute wealth justly
• Preventing powerful family members from monopolizing wealth

"Allah instructs you concerning your children: for the male, what is equal to the share of two females." (Quran 4:11)

This verse begins a detailed explanation of inheritance shares, showing that Allah Himself legislated these laws—not the Prophet ﷺ, not scholars, but Allah directly.

Why Inheritance Laws are Fixed by Allah:

The Prophet ﷺ said: "Give the obligatory shares to those who are entitled to them, and what remains goes to the nearest male heir." (Bukhari & Muslim)

The Prophet ﷺ also said: "Indeed, Allah has given every deserving person his right. So there is no will for an heir." (Tirmidhi - Sahih)

This means:
• You cannot change the shares Allah has determined
• You cannot disinherit someone Allah has given a share
• You cannot give extra inheritance to one heir over another
• These laws are divine protection against human greed and injustice

The Severe Consequences of Violating Inheritance Laws:

1. Allah's Direct Warning:

"And whoever disobeys Allah and His Messenger and transgresses His limits - He will put him into the Fire to abide eternally therein, and he will have a humiliating punishment." (Quran 4:14)

This verse comes immediately after the inheritance verses, showing the severity of violating these laws.

2. Consuming the Wealth of Orphans:

"Indeed, those who devour the property of orphans unjustly are only consuming into their bellies fire. And they will be burned in a Blaze." (Quran 4:10)

When someone dies, their minor children are orphans. Denying them their rightful inheritance is literally consuming fire.

3. Injustice to Daughters:

"When news is brought to one of them of the birth of a female child, his face darkens, and he is filled with inward grief! With shame does he hide himself from his people, because of the bad news he has had! Shall he retain it on sufferance and contempt, or bury it in the dust? Ah! What an evil choice they decide on?" (Quran 16:58-59)

Islam came to elevate women's status. Denying daughters their inheritance contradicts the very spirit of Islam.

4. Family Destruction:

The Prophet ﷺ said: "Learn about inheritance and teach it to the people, for it is half of knowledge, and it will be forgotten. This will be the first thing to be taken away from my Ummah." (Tirmidhi - Hasan)

Most family feuds and broken relationships stem from inheritance disputes. Following Islamic law prevents this.

Overview of Islamic Inheritance Laws:

Fixed Shares (Fard):
Allah has specified exact shares for:
• Spouse: 1/4 or 1/2 depending on presence of children
• Father: 1/6 when there are children
• Mother: 1/6 or 1/3 depending on circumstances
• Daughter(s): 1/2 for one daughter, 2/3 for two or more daughters
• Son(s): Residuary heirs (take what remains after fixed shares)
• Siblings: Various shares depending on other heirs
• Grandparents, uncles, cousins: Specified shares in specific circumstances

The Wisdom of "Male gets double the female":

"Allah instructs you concerning your children: for the male, what is equal to the share of two females." (Quran 4:11)

This is often misunderstood. The wisdom includes:
• Men are financially responsible for their wives, children, and sometimes extended family
• Women keep their inheritance entirely for themselves—no obligation to spend it on family
• Women receive mahr (dowry) upon marriage, which men don't receive
• The husband must provide for his wife even if she's wealthy
• Overall, when you calculate total wealth accumulation, women often end up with more

Example: A brother and sister each inherit. The brother gets 2 shares, sister gets 1 share. But the brother must use his wealth to pay mahr for marriage, provide for his wife and children, and help needy relatives. The sister keeps her inheritance, receives mahr, is provided for by her husband, and has no financial obligations. The apparent difference balances out.

IMPORTANT: The 2:1 Ratio is NOT Universal:

Many people mistakenly believe that women always get half of what men get in Islamic inheritance. This is incorrect! The 2:1 ratio applies ONLY to children inheriting from their parents when both sons and daughters are present.

There are many cases where women receive EQUAL or even MORE than men:

1. Mother vs Father: If a deceased person leaves only parents and a spouse, the mother inherits 1/3 while the father inherits 1/6 (mother gets DOUBLE the father's share!)

2. Husband and Wife: A husband inherits 1/4 or 1/2 depending on children, while a wife inherits 1/8 or 1/4. But considering the husband must spend his entire wealth on the family while the wife keeps hers, she may end up wealthier overall.

3. Daughters in certain scenarios: When there are only daughters and no sons, they receive 2/3 of the estate to share. If there's only one daughter, she gets 1/2.

4. Uterine siblings: Brothers and sisters from the same mother get equal shares when inheriting from each other.

The variation in shares is based on financial responsibility, not gender value. Islam was the first religion to grant women inheritance rights 1400+ years ago, a revolutionary reform when women were not even considered human in many cultures!

The Rights of All Heirs - 10+ Quranic Verses on Inheritance:

1. General Right to Inherit:
"For men is a share of what the parents and close relatives leave, and for women is a share of what the parents and close relatives leave, be it little or much—an obligatory share." (Quran 4:7)

2. Children's Shares:
"Allah instructs you concerning your children: for the male, what is equal to the share of two females. But if there are more than two daughters, they share two-thirds of what he left. And if there is only one, for her is half. And for one's parents, to each one of them is a sixth of his estate if he left children." (Quran 4:11)

3. Spouses' Shares:
"And for you is half of what your wives leave if they have no child. But if they have a child, for you is one fourth of what they leave, after any bequest they may have made or debt. And for the wives is one fourth if you leave no child. But if you leave a child, then for them is an eighth of what you leave, after any bequest you may have made or debt." (Quran 4:12)

4. Siblings' Shares:
"If a man or woman leaves neither ascendants nor descendants but has a brother or a sister, then for each one of them is a sixth. But if they are more than two, they share a third, after any bequest which was made or debt, as long as there is no detriment. This is an ordinance from Allah, and Allah is Knowing and Forbearing." (Quran 4:12)

5. The Finality of These Laws:
"These are the limits set by Allah. And whoever obeys Allah and His Messenger will be admitted to gardens beneath which rivers flow, abiding eternally therein; and that is the great attainment." (Quran 4:13)

6. The Punishment for Violation:
"And whoever disobeys Allah and His Messenger and transgresses His limits - He will put him into the Fire to abide eternally therein, and he will have a humiliating punishment." (Quran 4:14)

7. Kindness and Justice:
"And when [other] relatives and orphans and the needy are present at the [time of] division, then provide for them [something] out of the estate and speak to them words of appropriate kindness." (Quran 4:8)

Common Violations to Avoid:

1. Depriving Daughters:
In some cultures, daughters don't receive their shares. This is a major sin. The Prophet ﷺ said: "Whoever has three daughters, is patient with them, clothes them from his wealth—they will be a shield for him from the Fire." (Tirmidhi - Sahih) If daughters are so honored in life, how can we deny them their rights after death?

2. Favoring Some Children Over Others:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "Fear Allah and treat your children fairly." (Bukhari & Muslim) Giving preference to one child during life or through unequal distribution is unjust.

3. Using Cultural Traditions Instead of Islamic Law:
Many cultures have traditions that contradict Islam (only sons inherit, eldest son gets everything, etc.). The Prophet ﷺ said: "Whoever introduces anything into this matter of ours that is not part of it will have it rejected." (Bukhari & Muslim)

4. Delaying Distribution:
Some families delay inheritance distribution for years or decades, causing hardship for heirs who need their shares. This is injustice and oppression.

5. Hiding Assets:
Some executors hide assets from other heirs. This is betrayal of trust and theft. "Indeed, Allah commands you to render trusts to whom they are due." (Quran 4:58)

6. Giving Inheritance to Non-Heirs:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "Indeed Allah has appointed for everyone who has a right what is due to him, and no bequest must be made to an heir." (Tirmidhi - Sahih)

The Importance of Writing a Will (Wasiyyah):

The Prophet ﷺ said: "It is not permissible for any Muslim who has something to will to stay for two nights without having his last will and testament written and kept ready with him." (Bukhari & Muslim)

What Can You Include in a Will:

1. Up to One-Third for Non-Heirs:
You can will up to 1/3 of your estate to:
• Charity
• Distant relatives who don't inherit
• Friends
• Islamic causes
• Anyone except your heirs (they already have fixed shares)

2. Executor Appointment:
Name someone trustworthy to execute your will and distribute inheritance according to Islamic law.

3. Funeral Arrangements:
Simple, Sunnah-compliant funeral without extravagance.

4. Debt Acknowledgment:
List any debts you owe so they can be paid before inheritance distribution.

5. Guardians for Minor Children:
Name guardians to care for your children if both parents pass away.

What You CANNOT Do in a Will:

• Will more than 1/3 of your estate
• Give any portion to your heirs (they already have Allah-designated shares)
• Disinherit someone entitled to inheritance
• Contradict Islamic inheritance laws in any way

The Order of Inheritance Distribution:

1. Funeral Expenses: Simple, dignified Islamic burial
2. Outstanding Debts: All debts must be paid first
3. Bequests: Up to 1/3 for non-heirs
4. Inheritance: Remaining estate divided according to Islamic law

Avoiding Family Disputes Over Inheritance:

1. Get a Proper Islamic Inheritance Calculation:
Consult qualified Islamic scholars or use verified Islamic inheritance calculators to ensure proper distribution.

2. Distribute Promptly:
Don't delay. Heirs have immediate rights to their shares.

3. Transparent Accounting:
Provide clear documentation of all assets, debts, and calculations to all heirs.

4. Mediation by Respected Elders:
If disagreements arise, involve trusted family elders or Islamic scholars to mediate.

5. Remember the Hereafter:
Greed for worldly wealth that belongs to others is foolish when you'll face Allah soon.

Family Wealth Ethics Beyond Inheritance:

1. Spending on Poor Relatives:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "Charity to the poor is charity, but charity to a relative is two things: charity and upholding the ties of kinship." (Tirmidhi - Sahih)

2. Fair Distribution During Life:
The Prophet ﷺ said: "Fear Allah and be just among your children." (Bukhari & Muslim) Give gifts equally during your lifetime.

3. Not Letting Wealth Create Divisions:
Rich family members shouldn't look down on poor ones. Poor ones shouldn't envy the rich. "And lower your wing to those who follow you of the believers." (Quran 26:215)

4. Teaching Children About Halal Wealth:
"O you who have believed, indeed, intoxicants, gambling, [sacrificing on] stone altars [to other than Allah], and divining arrows are but defilement from the work of Satan, so avoid it that you may be successful." (Quran 5:90) Earn and spend only halal.

5. Avoiding Extravagance and Miserliness:
"And those who, when they spend, do so not excessively or sparingly but are ever, between that, [justly] moderate." (Quran 25:67)

Real-Life Scenarios and Solutions:

Scenario 1: Parents want to give their house to only one son who cared for them.
Solution: This is not permissible. All heirs must receive their Islamic shares. The caring son can be compensated during the parents' lifetime as a gift (which should still be fair to other children), but inheritance must follow Islamic law.

Scenario 2: A wealthy man has one daughter and wants to give everything to her.
Solution: The daughter gets her fixed share (1/2 as the only daughter). The remainder goes to other eligible heirs (his parents, siblings, etc.). He can give her extra during his lifetime or will up to 1/3 to her if she's not an heir at the time of death.

Scenario 3: Family members want to voluntarily give up their shares to help a needy sibling.
Solution: This is permissible AFTER they receive their shares and voluntarily, without pressure, give it as a gift to the needy sibling.

The Ultimate Perspective:

Allah says: "You know not whether your parents or your children are nearest to you in benefit. [These shares are] an obligation [imposed] by Allah. Indeed, Allah is ever Knowing and Wise." (Quran 4:11)

We don't know who will benefit us most before Allah—maybe the child we thought was least successful will be the one whose prayers save us in the grave. So trust Allah's distribution system.

The Prophet ﷺ said: "Whoever would like Allah to save him from the hardships of the Day of Resurrection, let him give more time to his debtor who is in difficulty, or let him write off the debt." (Muslim)

Give up some wealth now to gain eternal rewards. Don't destroy family bonds over temporary worldly possessions that you'll leave behind anyway.

Conclusion:

Inheritance law is where family bonds are either strengthened or shattered. By following Allah's perfect system, we protect relationships, ensure justice, and earn divine pleasure. Violating it brings Allah's anger, family destruction, and Hellfire.

Make your will today. Learn Islamic inheritance law. Teach it to your family. Ensure justice for all heirs. This is half of knowledge, as the Prophet ﷺ said, and protecting it protects the Ummah.

وراثت اور خاندانی دولت

اسلامی وراثت کے قوانین خاندانی بندھن کو محفوظ رکھتے اور انصاف کو یقینی بناتے ہیں۔

الٰہی تقسیم:
• "مردوں کے لیے حصہ ہے جو والدین اور قریبی رشتہ دار چھوڑیں، اور عورتوں کے لیے بھی حصہ ہے جو والدین اور قریبی رشتہ دار چھوڑیں۔" (قرآن 4:7)
• وراثت کے قوانین اللہ نے مقرر کیے ہیں
• اختیاری یا کسی کے ذریعہ تبدیل نہیں کیے جا سکتے
• ان کی خلاف ورزی کبیرہ گناہوں میں سے ہے

اسلامی قانون کی پیروی کی اہمیت:
• نبی کریم ﷺ نے فرمایا: "حصے حقداروں کو دو، اور جو بچے وہ قریب ترین مرد وارث کو جائے۔" (بخاری و مسلم)
• تمام خاندانی اراکین کے حقوق کی حفاظت
• جھگڑوں اور ناانصافی سے بچاتا ہے
• عورتوں کے حقوق کی ضمانت

عام خلاف ورزیاں جن سے بچنا چاہیے:
• بیٹیوں کو ان کے حصے سے محروم کرنا
• ایک بچے کو دوسرے پر ترجیح دینا
• اسلامی قانون کی بجائے ثقافتی روایات استعمال کرنا
• وراثت کی تقسیم میں تاخیر
• حقدار وارثوں سے اثاثے چھپانا

ناانصافی کا گناہ:
• "بیشک جو یتیموں کا مال ناحق کھاتے ہیں وہ اپنے پیٹ میں صرف آگ بھرتے ہیں۔" (قرآن 4:10)
• کسی کا حق لینا شدید ظلم ہے
• قیامت کے دن جوابدہ ہوں گے
• خاندانی رشتوں کو تباہ کر سکتا ہے

اپنی وصیت تیار کرنا:
• اسلامی قانون کے مطابق وصیت لکھیں
• اپنی جائیداد کے 1/3 سے زیادہ کی وصیت نہیں کر سکتے
• وارث کو وراثت نہیں دے سکتے (ان کے پہلے سے مقررہ حصے ہیں)
• 1/3 غیر وارثوں کے لیے ہے (صدقہ، دور کے رشتہ دار وغیرہ)
• نبی کریم ﷺ نے فرمایا: "کسی بھی مسلمان کے لیے جس کے پاس وصیت کرنے کی کوئی چیز ہو، دو راتیں گزارنا جائز نہیں کہ اس کی وصیت لکھی ہوئی نہ ہو۔" (بخاری و مسلم)

اتحاد برقرار رکھنا:
• وراثت فوری طور پر تقسیم کریں
• اپنے حصے پر مطمئن رہیں
• دولت پر مقابلہ یا جھگڑا نہ کریں
• یاد رکھیں: "تم اسے دوسروں کے لیے چھوڑ جاؤ گے"
• جھگڑے پیدا ہونے سے پہلے صلح کریں
• واضح نہ ہو تو اسلامی علماء سے مدد لیں

خاندانی دولت کی رہنمائی:
• پہلے غریب رشتہ داروں پر خرچ کریں
• دولت کے فرق کی وجہ سے رشتے نہ توڑیں
• امیر غریب خاندانی اراکین کی مدد کریں
• دولت کا دکھاوا کرنے سے بچیں
• بچوں کو دولت کے صحیح انتظام کے بارے میں سکھائیں
• صرف حلال آمدنی کمائیں

• नबी करीम ﷺ ने फ़रमाया: "हिस्से हक़दारों को दो, और जो बचे वो क़रीबतरीन मर्द वारिस को जाए।" (बुख़ारी व मुस्लिम)
• तमाम ख़ानदानी अराकीन के हुक़ूक़ की हिफ़ाज़त
• झगड़ों और नाइंसाफ़ी से बचाता है
• औरतों के हुक़ूक़ की ज़मानत

आम ख़िलाफ़वर्ज़ियां जिनसे बचना चाहिए:
• बेटियों को उनके हिस्से से महरूम करना
• एक बच्चे को दूसरे पर तरजीह देना
• इस्लामी क़ानून की बजाए सक़ाफ़ती रिवायतें इस्तेमाल करना
• विरासत की तक़सीम में तअख़ीर
• हक़दार वारिसों से असासे छुपाना

नाइंसाफ़ी का गुनाह:
• "बेशक जो यतीमों का माल नाहक़ खाते हैं वो अपने पेट में सिर्फ़ आग भरते हैं।" (क़ुरआन 4:10)
• किसी का हक़ लेना शदीद ज़ुल्म है
• क़यामत के दिन जवाबदेह होंगे
• ख़ानदानी रिश्तों को तबाह कर सकता है

अपनी वसीयत तैयार करना:
• इस्लामी क़ानून के मुताबिक़ वसीयत लिखें
• अपनी जायदाद के 1/3 से ज़्यादा की वसीयत नहीं कर सकते
• वारिस को विरासत नहीं दे सकते (उनके पहले से मुक़र्ररा हिस्से हैं)
• 1/3 ग़ैर वारिसों के लिए है (सदक़ा, दूर के रिश्तेदार वग़ैरह)
• नबी करीम ﷺ ने फ़रमाया: "किसी भी मुसलमान के लिए जिसके पास वसीयत करने की कोई चीज़ हो, दो रातें गुज़ारना जाइज़ नहीं कि उसकी वसीयत लिखी हुई न हो।" (बुख़ारी व मुस्लिम)

इत्तेहाद बरक़रार रखना:
• विरासत फ़ौरन तक़सीम करें
• अपने हिस्से पर मुतमइन रहें
• दौलत पर मुक़ाबला या झगड़ा न करें
• याद रखें: "तुम इसे दूसरों के लिए छोड़ जाओगे"
• झगड़े पैदा होने से पहले सुलह करें
• वाज़ेह न हो तो इस्लामी उलमा से मदद लें

ख़ानदानी दौलत की रहनुमाई:
• पहले ग़रीब रिश्तेदारों पर ख़र्च करें
